georged

Unless running significant graphic or calculating software, IMO few people will ever notice the difference. Serious gamers, the upper end of the market for processors/memory and test beds for many high-end systems, seldom choose AMD.
daewoo

Unless running significant graphic or calculating software, IMO few people will ever notice the difference. Serious gamers, the upper end of the market for processors/memory and test beds for many high-end systems, seldom choose AMD.

 
 We run a lot of pretty serious engineering software, mostly on multiple processor machines. 
 
 For single processor machines, it is pretty much a tossup in most categories, since the bus speed of the AMD is lower, but command execution is faster. The two tend to kind of balance each other out. The AMD is usually faster from a practical standpoint, though, because your machine is basically the slave tot he slowest component, and in software with process seperation as bad as windows has, a slow USB application can literally slow down the entire machine.
 
 In multiple processor machines, with the exception of some server configuratyions utilizing the xeon processors and applications specifically designed for them, a multiple processor AMD system is noticably faster than a multiple processor Intel based machine. You are again moving out of windows land here, though, since windows support for multiple processors is pretty bad. 
 
 In the end, it probably doesn't really matter one way or the other. If you are using windows, go with the cheapest of the two. If you want to upgrade from windows to a *nix variation, go with a multiple processor AMD setup if you just HAVE to have a 32 bit processor. For the money, though, a 64 bit based unit is an even better value.

 If all you want is something that will run basic WP functions and the like, look on Ebay fro an itronix. They only run 200 MHZ, generally windows 95, and most on Ebay only have 32 MB ram. You can get a 64 MB expansion module (which is actually overkill since windows 9x can only utilize 64 mb) and it will more than run your word processing functions. If you stick with office 97, it will likely outpace tyour desktop machine, assuming you are running office 2K or newer on your desktop.
 
 The real advantage to the itronix is that they are nigh indestructible. We used to use them around work. I saw one knocked off of a railing, fall 2 stories onto the tile floor below, and it survived just fine. I would not make a habit of doing that, but it is nice to know, as you watch your laptop fall through the air, that there is SOME hope for it.

daewoo

Can't argue with durability. But, compared to XP, Win 9x will drive IT work station maintenance crazy as it always has. Smaller businesses with no inhouse IT support on simple networks have reduced their outside IT costs up to 50% by going to XP. Even the least skilled data input drones and admin assistants using Power Point and Access have trouble crashing or slowing down XP.

 
 Overall, though, when one consideres the upgraded hardware requirements for XP, as well as its marginal (at best ) support for server run apps, I think 9x or 2000 is still the better option. In XP, they slowed down execution of remote apps intentionally in order to increase their reliabililty. While this makes great sense from a purely IT standpoint, it also means your employees spending more time sitting in front of their machines waiting for something to happen. If your business is small enough, this makes no difference. 
 
 Most companies with data intensive remote applications (phone companies, etc...) are still runnning NT on clients, and Win2K on workstations. 
 
 Companies seem to have learned their lesson when it somes to MS products. Major players tend to lag behind by several years. I know that yellow freight finished an upgrade juast last year from windows 95, and over half of comapnies are still running NT 4.0.

 RIPOFF. You can get a 2650pro, exactly the same as the one in the auction, for $120.00 plus $18 shipping from www.tirelesswireless.com . They have one with a 6 GB hard drive for $140. I have dealt with them before (IIRC the guys name is michael) and they are good folks. You can definatly trust him. 
 
 On another note, anybody looking for a goo, fast machine, seearch for honeywell FMT on Ebay. They are selling a sun microsystems 6500 server. 12x400mhz 64 bit processors, 22GB ram. Nothing micorsoft makes will really support that many processors, but just about any *nix variant will, and if you REALLY need the microsoft virus on your machine, you can run it in VMware and it will pretty much run like it is running on all processors. You WILL have the fastest computer on your block!!

 The wireless capability on an itronix is worthless. What the guy is calling "wireless networking" is NOT 802.11 or ranglan compliant. It is CPDP. BAsically a slow cellular modem. NOBODY supports it anymore, so you may as well leave it off and save the battery. 
 
 The 6250 did not have many optional components. USB and memory size is about it. Everything else is the same regardless of where you get it.
